text.p: Bear plays dominated coffee options activity this week as implied volatilities came under pressure, traders said.
After an uneventful expiry of November options on Wednesday, interest shifted to the second-month January $1,400 puts with coffee sellers interested in defending against the downside.

One strategy involved buying the January $1,400 put and selling the March $1,550 or $1,600 call to finance the put -- a deal that traders say places emphasis on protecting the buyer of the put from downside risk without having to pay up.
"If you have coffee, you want to protect the downside and if the market goes up you have the coffee anyway," said one market maker.
"You set the level that you are prepared to sell your coffee, and $200 above the market is quite a good sell," he added.
Coffee futures have been trapped in a narrow range this week, with a daily dose of origin selling keeping a lid on any upside attempts.
Traders reckoned prices could drop further when Central American produce comes on stream after generous supplies from Africa and the Far East this year.

Robusta players have ignored recent bullish movements on the arabicas market, where the market had corrected lower into a good area of support. On Thursday, January futures stood $9 lower before the close at $1,425 a tonne.
"The bearish fence just sums the sentiment up," said the options trader.
The January $1,750 and $1,900 call spread was also in the spotlight as players rolled down their strike parallel to the futures market.
Volatilies were a touch off last week's levels. January at-the-money calls and puts were trading around 27-29 percent while March calls came under increased pressure, trading at 24-25 percent.
The expiry of November options triggered some delta hedging on Wednesday as the futures approached the $1,550 mark where some 550 lots of open interest had accumulated.
Traders said last minute buying pushed November futures $20 higher just before the midday expiry but the contract stopped short of the options trigger at $1,547.
Options turnover reached 4,025 lots so far this week.
